properties.Name:
Former KCBX Terminals North Site

3259 E 100th St Chicago IL 60617
properties.EPA: Full archive of EPA's confrontation with KCBX over the petcoke issue.
properties.website:
Was it a victory? This site was closed in 2015 in response to municipal regulation, but also as part of an already planned transfer of all of KCBX's petcoke and coal operations to the South Terminal just a short distance down the river. The fact is that the Koch Brothers are still moving carbon dust through Southeast Chicago neighborhoods, and they intend to continue, just as the neighborhoods intend to keep on fighting to stop them.

FURTHER INFO: Initial comments on proposed dust regulations; see the Chicago Dept of Public Health website for the full correspondence on the issue.

properties.Name:
Holcim Inc

3020 E 103rd St. Chicago, IL 60617
properties.EPA: EPA facility report, link to company website
properties.website: After the petcoke controversey led to the drafting of new municipal health department regulations, Holcim like so many of the other bulk materials handlers rushed to inform the city that their dust, unlike petcoke, was just dust. Yet the whole point is right there: any fine dust causes asthma and other respiratory conditions.

properties.Name:
KCBX Terminals South Site

10730 S Burley Ave Chicago IL 60617
properties.Image: photo Terry Evans (click for enlargement)
properties.EPA:
FURTHER INFO: To grasp the intimate relation between this toxic site and the surrounding neighborhoods, see the photoreportage by artist Terry Evans. For a chronology of the struggles surrounding fugitive dust from the petcoke piles, see the archive of NRDC articles on the issue. For the legal maneuvers between the City of Chicago, environmental organizations and terminal operators such as KCBX, see the full correspondence between the parties on the Chicago Dept of Public Health website
.
properties.website: On this site, KCBX Terminals, aka the infamous Koch Brothers, runs a petcoke stockpile that poisons the neighborhood with dust before poisoning the world when it is ultimately burned as fuel. Tar sands oil produces huge quantities of it. The business model of the Kochs is to buy up cheap industrial junk and use it 'till bust. In this case they saw the tar sands bonanza coming, so they bought an abandoned steel site with a train track and a river dock in order to trade in dirty energy right in the middle of a populated neighborhood. Material is brought in by train and barge from the Citgo and ExxonMobile refineries located to the southeast, then shipped out by train, barge or freighter. It is said to go to foreign buyers, but no one really knows. It was probably obvious to Koch company managers that people in the area would protest against this business, and it was also probably obvious that they could make a lot of money in the interim. For more, read the materials linked below and look at the other open pile sites marked on this map. The struggle is still ongoing.

properties.Name:
Former Calumet Transload Facility (Beemsterboer Slag Corp)

106th and Calumet River Chicago IL 60617
properties.Image: For images of the piles, see the photo-reportage by Zbigniew Bzdak in the Chicago Tribune.
properties.EPA: FURTHER INFO: Full archive of EPA's confrontation with Beemsterboer over the petcoke issue
properties.website: On August 30, 2013, a windstorm blew clouds of petcoke dust across Southeast Chicago neighborhoods, coating everything in a layer of grime and rendering one conclusion inescapable: the inhabitants were being poisoned by this fine particulate, whose degree of toxicity is unknown. The operator of this site, a local business named Beemsterboer, closed its petcoke operation in September 2014 under intense pressure from the neighborhoods, the EPA and the city government, as recounted in the Chicago Tribune and the Northwest Indiana Times.

properties.Name:
Gulf Sulpher Services, subsidiary of Savage Services Corp

12200 S Carondolet Ave Chicago IL 60633

properties.Image: photo Claire Pentecost (click for enlargement)
properties.Name:
Horsehead Corporation

2701 E 114th St Chicago IL 60617
properties.EPA:
Horsehead's variance request to the fugitive dust regulations and subsequent modifications
SETF/NRDC's response to the variance request
properties.Notes: Horsehead recycles electric arc furnace dust from the steel industry to make a 60% zinc feedstock for use in its North Carolina plant. It also makes a 50% iron product used as aggregate in asphalt and as a passive water treatment. To do this it burns coke, formerly petcoke and now only metallurgical coke or metcoke. The whole site is black with coke and piles of it could be seen on the river bank in summer 2015. It's not clear why EPA has only one toxic release report on Horsehead; maybe because of its designation as a recycling facility?

properties.Name:
Beelman River Terminals Inc

10459 S Muskegon Ave Chicago IL 60617
properties.Notes: Beelman is a trucking company, but they operate this river terminal and another one at their home base in St Louis. The uncovered pile (lime?) was seen in summer 2015.
